if granny could see these big chaps, (whilst carrying ledgers) all full of £ s. d., and me as much at home with them as old Miggles with his toy terriers. (puts books on desk and returns to c.)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (L.) Only the outsides, Sam—fifty—fifty-one—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Everything must have a beginning. I'm only under messenger now, at six bob a week, but it's the small end of the wedge. I don't mean to stay running errands and dusting books long, I can tell you. I intend to speculate—I'm in two tips already.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Tips?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes. (takes out betting book) I stand to win a fiver on Pollux for the Derby, and a good thing on the Count for the Ascot Cup—they were at Pollux last week, but he's all right again, and the Count's in splendid form, and the stable uncommon sweet on him.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Bring me those pens. (as SAM comes to him with the pens he comes to c. and catches him by the collar and shakes him) You young rascal! Now, you mark me, Master Sam. If ever I hear of you putting into a tip again I'll thrash you within an inch of your life, and then I'll split on you to Mr. Gibson, and he'll discharge you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Now I call that mean. One City gent interfering with another City gent's amusements.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (bitterly) Amusements! When you've seen as much as I have, you'll know what comes of such amusements, lad.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: As if I didn't know well enough already. Lark, lush, and a latch-key—a swell rig out, and lots of ready in the pockets—a drag at Epsom, and a champagne lunch on the hill! Oh my—ain't it stunning!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Ah, Sam, that's the fancy picture—mine is the true one. Excitement first, then idleness and drink, and then bad companions—sin—shame—and a prison.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Come, I don't want to be preached to in office hours: granny gives me quite enough of that at home, ain't it a bore, just!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Oh, my lad, take my advice, do! Be steady— stick to work and home. It's an awful look out for a young chap adrift in this place, without them sheet anchors. (returns to counter, L.)

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh, I ain't afraid. I cut my eye teeth early. Tips ain't worse than time bargains—and they're business. (crosses at back to his L.) But don't look glum, Bob, you're the right sort, you are, and sooner than rile you I'll cut tips, burn "Bell's Life, and take to Capel Court and the "Share List," and that's respectable, you know. (sits on counter)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (looking over cheque book) You young rascal! you've made me misnumber my cheques.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Serves you jolly well right, for coming to business on your wedding day.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Oh! I've two hours good before I'm wanted for that.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I say, Bob, you don't mean to say you've been to the Bank for the petty cash this morning?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And didn't leave the notes on the counter?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: And didn't have your pocket picked?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Well, you are a cool hand. I've often wondered how the poor chaps in Newgate managed to eat a good breakfast before they're turned off. But a fellow coming to office the morning he's going to be spliced and when the Governor has given him a holiday too—by Jove, it beats the Old Bailey by lengths. I hope I shall be as cool when I'm married.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: You you young cock-sparrow.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Yes. I've ordered the young woman I want down at Birmingham. Miss Edwards ain't my style.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: No—isn't she though? I'm sorry it's too late to have her altered.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: She's too quiet—wants go. I like high action. Now I call Mrs. Jones a splendid woman. Sam Willoughby, Esquire, must have a real tip-top lady. I don't mean to marry till I can go to church with my own brougham.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I suppose that means when you've set up as a crossing sweeper. And now, Sam, till your brougham comes round for you, just trot off to the stationer's and see if Mr. Gibson's new bill-case is ready.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (vaulting over the counter, sees MAY through the glass door, L., off L. 1 E.) All right. Here's Miss Edwards a coming in full tog. I twig—I ain't wanted. Quite correct—Samivel is fly.

div.stage: Puts his finger to his nose and Exit c.
Enter MAY, L., in wedding dress.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Ah, May darling! (takes her by the hand and kisses her)

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (looking in) I saw you!

div.stage: Exit, C. L.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (R.) Hang that boy! But never mind his impudence, my own little wife.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Not yet, sir.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: In two hours.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: There's many a slip between the cup and the lip, you know. But as the clerks aren't come yet, I thought I might just look in and shew you (displays her dress)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Your wedding gown!

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Yes. It's Mrs. Gibson's present, with such a kind note—and she insists on providing the wedding breakfast and she's sent in the most beautiful cake, and flowers from their own conservatory. My little room looks so pretty.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: It always looks pretty when thou art in it. I shall never miss the sun, even in Nicholas Lane, after we are married, darling.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Oh! Robert, won't it be delightful? Me, house-keeper here, and you, messenger, and such a favorite too! And to think we owe all, to these good kind generous —There's only one thing I can't get off my mind.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Mr. Gibson doesn't know the truth about you. We should have told him before this.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: It's hard for a poor chap that's fought clear of the mud, to let go the rope he's holding to and slide back again. I'll tell him when I've been long enough here to try me, only wait a bit.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Perhaps you are right, dear. Sometimes the thought comes like a cloud across me. But you've never said how you like my dress. (displaying it)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I couldn't see it for looking at thy bonny face— but it's a grand gown. (get round at back to L.)

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And my own making! I forgot—Mrs. Jones is come, and Mrs. Willoughby. They're going to church with us you know — Emily looks so nice—she would so like to see the office, she says, if I might bring her in?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Oh, yes! the place is free to the petticoats till business hours.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (crosses L. and calls at door, L.) Come in, Emily.

div.stage: Enter MRS. GREEN JONES, L

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh! Mr. Brierly.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: While Robert does the honours of the office, I'll go and help Mrs. Willoughby to set out the breakfast. The white service looks so lovely, Robert, and my canary sings as I haven't heard him since I left the old lodgings. He knows there's joy in the wind.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (calling without, L.) Miss Edwards!

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: There! I'm wanted. I'm coming, Mrs. Willoughby. Oh, dear! If I'd known the trouble it was to be married, I don't think I should have ventured. I'm coming.

div.stage: Exit, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (who has been looking about her) I did so want to see an office—a real one, you know. I've seen'em set on the stage often, but they ain't a bit like the real thing.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: They are but dull places. Not this one, though, since May's been housekeeper.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes, they are dull, but so respectable—look so like money, you know. I suppose, now, there's no end of money passes here?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: A hundred thousand pounds a day, sometimes.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Gracious goodness! All in sovereigns?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Not a farthing—all in cheques and bills. We've a few thousands, that a queer old fashioned depositor insists on Mr. Gibson keeping here, but except that, and the petty cash, there's no hard money in the place.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Dear me! I thought you City people sat on stools all day shovelling sovereigns about. Not that I could bear to think of Jones sitting on a stool all day, even to shovel about sovereigns, though he always says
something in the City would suit him better than the comic duet business. But he doesn't know what's good for him—never did, poor fellow.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Except when he married you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, I don't know about that, but I suppose he would have got through the property without me he's so much the gentleman, you know.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: He's coming to church with us?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, yes! You know he's to give away the bride. But he was obliged to keep an appointment in the City first, so queer for Jones, wasn't it? He wouldn't tell me what it was.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: (heard without, L. C.,) Two and six, my man. Very good, wait.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Here's your husband!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (looking through door, c.) In a cab—and a new coat and waistcoat, and trousers! Oh, Jones! Well, I shan't pay for them.

div.stage: Enter GREEN JONES, L. C., in a gorgeous new suit.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: (speaking off) Now, hand me out those parcels—yah, stupid, give me hold. (hands in parcels one by one) Here, bear a hand. (he pitches parcels to BRIERLY, who pitches them on to MRS. GREEN JONES, who deposits them on the counter, L.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (as first bonnet box comes in) Jones! (as second bonnet box comes in) Green! (as case of Eau-de-Cologne comes in) Green Jones! (glove box comes in) Oh! (two bouquets in paper are given in) Gracious goodness!

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: There all out. Let's see—bonnets, Eau-de-Cologne, gloves, bouquets—seven ten; Two and six the cab—my own togs, five ten—that's thirteen two and six in all.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Jones, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Is your principal here, Brierly?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: The governor? No, it's not his time yet.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: En attendant, you couldn't advance me thirteen two six, could you?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: What! lend you the money?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
(reproachfully) Oh, Jones! I'm afraid——
you're as great a fool as ever.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Emily, be calm. It's not the least consequence. They can wait—the shopman, I mean —that is— the two shopmen and cabby.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, he's gone crazy!

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: The fact is, I've had a windfall. Choker Black has turned up trumps. He was put in the hole in California's year, had to bolt to Australia--struck an awfully full pocket at the diggings, and is paying off his old ticks like an emperor. He let me in for two thousand, and he has sent me bills for five hundred, as a first instalment.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Five hundred! And you've got the money?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: I've got the bills on his agent. Here they are. Emily, embrace your husband! (he kisses her)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (R.) I wish you joy—both of you. Mr. Gibson will discount the bills for you as soon as he comes in.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: (c.) But, I say, cash, you know, no curious sherry--no old masters, or patent filters—I've had rather too much of that sort of thing in my time.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (L. who has been peeping into bonnet box) What a duck of a bonnet!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: No, you're not among your old sixty per cent. friends here. We only do good bills at the market rate.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (who has opened glove box) And what loves of gloves!

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: That's your sort. I feel now the full value of the commercial principle.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, Green! But you'll be careful of the money?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Careful! I'm an altered man. I swear—you'll allow me to register a vow in your office? —to devote myself to the virtuous pursuit of money-making. I'm worth five hundred pounds, I've fifteen hundred more coming in; — Not one farthing of that money shall go in foolish extravagance.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: But how about these things, Jones?

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Trifles; —a cadeau de noce for the ladies, and a case of Eau-de-Cologne for myself. I've been running to seed so long, and want watering so much. (sprinkles himself with Eau-de-Cologne)

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh dear, Green! I'm afraid you're as great a fool as ever.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Mrs. Jones—no man's a fool with £500 in his pocket. But here come the clerks;—band-boxes and bouquets ain't business-like. You must carry these down to May.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: (loading EMILY with the parcels) Beg her acceptance of a bonnet, a bouquet, and a box of Piver's seven and a quarter's; and accept the same yourself, from yours ever affectionately, G. J. (tries to kiss her over the parcels but cannot)

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (from over the parcels) Oh, go along with your nonsense! I'll give you one down stairs.

div.stage: Exit L. 1 E.
Enter MR. BURTON and MR. SHARPE, clerks, L. C.

sp.speaker: Sharpe.
sp.p: Good morning. Governor come yet?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Not yet, Mr. Sharpe; it's getting near his time, though.

stage.stage: (CLERKS hang up their hats, coats, &c., and seat themselves at desks, L.)

sp.speaker: Sharpe
sp.p: (to MR. GREEN JONES) Can we do anything for you, sir?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (indicating GREEN JONES) This gentleman's waiting to see Mr. Gibson. Here he is.

div.stage: Enter MR. GIBSON, L. C.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (rubbing his feet on the mat) Good morning, morning, Mr. Sharpe—good morning, Burton. Well, Robert—didn't expect to find you at the office this morning.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Here's a gentleman waiting for you, sir, on business.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: If you'll walk into my room, sir?

div.stage: Exit GREEN JONES into MR. GIBSON's room, R. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (R.) I thought I might as well number the cheques, sir, and go for the petty cash. Somehow, I felt I shouldn't like anything to go wrong to-day.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (c.) Well, that's a very proper feeling. I hope May likes my wife's present. She is a first-rate house-keeper; though she did call you her brother, the little rogue—and I've every reason to be satisfied with you.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I'm right proud of that, sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p:
You won't mind my giving you a word of advice on your wedding-day? Go on as you've begun— keep a bright eye and an enquiring tongue in your head
—learn how business is done—watch the market—and from what I've seen of you the six months you've been here, I shouldn't wonder if I found a better berth than messenger for you one of these days.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Mr. Gibson—sir—I can't thank you—but a look-out like that—it takes a man's breath away.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: In the City there's no gap between the first round of the ladder and the top of the tree. But that gentleman's waiting. (pauses—goes to door, R.) By-the-way! I expect a call from a Mr. Hawkshaw.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (starting) Hawkshaw!

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Yes, the famous detective. Shew him in when he comes. I've a particular appointment with him.

div.stage: Exit MR. GIBSON into his own room, R.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Hawkshaw coming here! The principal witness against me at my trial. Perhaps he won't know me—I'm much changed. But they say, at Portland, he never forgets a face. If he knows me, and tells Mr. Gibson, he'll discharge me—and, to-day, just when we looked to be so happy! It would break May's heart. But why should I stay? I'm free for the day—I will not wait to meet my ruin. (going up, c.)

div.stage: Enter HAWKSHAW, L. C.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (R. C.) Mr. Gibson within?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (L. C.) Yes, sir, but he has a gentleman with him.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Take in my name. (writes on card with pencil and gives it to BRIERLY)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (takes card and crossing to R. sees name on it— aside) Hawkshaw! It is too late! Would you like to look at the paper, sir? (offers him one from desk)

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (as he takes it, gives a keen look of recognition at BRIERLY, who shrinks under his eye, but represses his agitation by an effort) I've seen you before, I think?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I don't recollect you, sir.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p:
(carelessly) Perhaps I'm wrong—though I've a good memory for faces. Take in my card. BRIERLY goes off, R., with card. (sits, L.) It's Dalton's pal—the youngster who got four years for passing forged Bank of England paper, at the Belle Vue Tea Gardens. I owe Master Dalton one for
that night yet. Back from Portland, eh? Looks all the better for his schooling. But Portland's an odd shop to take an office messenger from. I wonder if his employer got his character from his last place.

div.stage: Re-enter BRIERLY, R.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Mr. Gibson will see you in a moment, sir.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Very well. (gives him a look)

div.stage: Re-enter GREEN JONES, from Mr. Gibson's room, R., with cheque.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: (to BRIELY) All right! Market rate—and no old masters. I'll drive to the bank—cash this—settle with those counter-skippers, and rattle back in time to see you turned off. I say you must allow me to order a little dinner at the "Star and Garter," and drive you down—all right, you know. Mail phæton and pair —your wife and my wife. I want to show you the style G. J. used to do it in. (goes up) Now, cabby, pull round. (speaking loud) London Joint Stock Bank! Best pace.

div.stage: Exit GREEN JONES, L. C.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (aside) He little thinks what may be hanging over me.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (appearing at the door of his room, R.) Now, Mr. Hawkshaw, I'm at your service.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (crosses to R., then returning BRIERLY the paper) Cool case of note-passing that at Bow-street, yesterday. (BRIERLY winces—aside) It's my man, sure enough!

div.stage: Exit into MR. GIBSON's room, R.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: He knows me —I can read it in his face—his voice. He'll tell Mr. Gibson! Perhaps he's telling him now! I wish I'd spoken to him—but they have no mercy. Oh, if I'd only made a clean breast of it to Mr. Gibson before this!

div.stage: Enter GIBSON and HAWKSHAW from MR. GIBSON's room, R.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (to first clerk) Mr. Sharpe; will you go round to the banks and see what's doing? SHARPE takes his hat and exit, L. C. Mr. Burton, you'll be just in time for morning's clearance.

sp.speaker: Burton.
sp.p: (getting his hat—aside) By Jove, the governor wants to make a morning's clearance of us, I think. I'm half an hour too soon for the clearing house. —Time for a tip-top game at billiards.

div.stage: Exit, L. C.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Robert! (writing at desk, R.)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Before you leave just step round to Glynn's and get me cash for this. You'll have time enough before you're wanted downstairs, you rascal.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (aside) He knows nothing. (aloud) I'll be back in five minutes, sir. (as GIBSON is about to give him the cheque HAWKSHAW who is standing between GIBSON and BRIERLY, interposes and takes cheque carelessly)

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (R. C.) Your messenger, eh?

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (R.) Yes.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Had him long?

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Six months.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Good character?

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Never had a steadier, soberer, better behaved lad in the office.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Had you references with him?

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Why I think I took him mainly on the strength of his own good looks and his sweetheart's. An honest face is the best testimonial after all.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: H'm—neither is always to be relied on.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: You detectives would suspect your own fathers. Why how you look at the lad. Come, you've never had him through your hands. (a pause)

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (R. C.) No, he's quite a stranger to me. (turns away) Here's the cheque, young man. Take care you make no mistake about it.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (aside, going, c.) Saved! saved! Heaven bless him for those words.

div.stage: Exit, L. C.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (aside) Poor devil, he's paid his debt at Portland. (aloud) Now to our business. You say a bill drawn by Vanzeller and Co. of Penang, on the London Joint-Stock Bank, was presented for discount here last night, which you know to be a forgery?

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Yes. As it was after hours the clerk told the presenter to call this morning.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Bill forging is tip-top work. The man who did this job knows what he's about. We mustn't alarm him. What time did the clerk tell him to call?

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: At eleven.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: It's within five minutes. You go to your room. I'll take my place at one of these desks as a clerk and send the customers in to you. When the forged bill is presented, you come to the door and say, loud enough for me to hear—"Vanzeller and Co., Penang," and leave the rest to me.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (nervously) Hadn't I better have assistance within call?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Oh dear no—I like to work single handed— but don't be excited. Take it coolly, or you may frighten the bird. (goes to desk, L.)

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Easy to say take it coolly! I haven't been thief catching all my life.

div.stage: Exit GIBSON into his room, R.
Enter MOSS, C., and down, C.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (at the counter, getting out his bills) Let me see —Spelter and Wayne. Fifty, ten, three—thirty days after sight. That's commercial. (examining another bill) For two hundred at two months—drawn by Captain Crabos—accepted the Honourable Augustus Greenway: that's a thirty per center. Better try that at another shop. (takes out another) Mossop and Mills—good paper —ninety-nine, eight, two—at sixty days. That'll do here.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (at door of his room, R.) Mr. Hawkshaw!

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: H-sh! (crosses to R., warns him against using name, but obeys his call, and goes in)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (on hearing name) Hawkshaw! (with a quick glance as HAWKSHAW passes into MR. GIBSON's room) A detective here! Ware —hawk! (alarmed, but recovering) Well, it ain't for me— I'm all on the square, now. If bills will go missing—it ain't me that steals 'em—Tiger does that —I'm always a bonâ fide holder for value—I can face any examination, I can. But I should like to know Hawkshaw's little game, and I shouldn't mind spoiling it. Re-enter HAWKSHAW, R. Mr. Gibson, if you please?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: He's in his office, sir. (as MOSS passes in he recognizes him—Exit MOSS, R.) Melter Moss here! Can he be the forger? He heard my name. Dear, dear, to think that a business-man like Mr. Gibson should be green enough to call a man like me by his name. Re-enter MOSS, R. Here he comes, now for the signal. (goes to desk, L.)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (coming down with cheques and bill book) All right! Beautiful paper, most of it. Only two of 'em fishy. Well, I'll try them three doors down—they ain't so particular.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (aside) No signal!

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (in front of counter, L.) If you'll allow me, I'll take a dip of your ink, young man—I've an entry to make in my bill book. (HAWKSHAW pitches him a pen) Thank you. (MOSS writes)

div.stage: Enter DALTON, L. C., dressed as a respectable elderly commercial man, in as complete contrast as possible with his appearance in first Act—comes down, C.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Mr. Gibson? (takes out his bill case)

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (at desk, L.) You'll find him in his office, sir.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (aside) That's not the young man I saw here yesterday afternoon. (aloud) Let me see first that I've got the bill. (rummages for bill)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (recognizing DALTON) Tiger here, in his City get up. Oh, oh! If this should be Hawkshaw's little game? I'll drop him a line. (writes, crosses to c., and passes paper secretly to DALTON, with a significant look, and taking care to keep behind the railing of the counter)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (recognizing him) Moss! (taking paper, reads) "Hawkshaw's at that desk." Forewarned, forearmed! (goes up)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (goes up, c.) There, I hope I've spoiled Hawkshaw's little game.

div.stage: Exit MOSS.
MR. GIBSON appears at door of office, R.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (about to address HAWKSHAW again) Mr.—

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (hastily interrupting him) H'sh! a party wants to see you, sir, if you could step this way, for a moment.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p:
Would you oblige me, Mr. Gibson, by looking
very particularly at this bill. (gives it to GIBSON, who comes down)

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (c.) "Vanzeller and Co., Penang." (glances at HAWKSHAW, aside, who crosses and seats himself at desk, R.) He don't stir! "Vanzeller and Co., Penang." (aside) Confound it, I haven't made a blunder, have I! "Vanzeller and Co., Penang." (HAWKSHAW prepares handcuffs under the desk)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Yes, a most respectable firm. But all's not gold that glitters; I thought the paper as safe as you do; but, unluckily, I burnt my fingers with it once before. You may or may not remember my presenting a bill drawn by the same firm for discount two months ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Yes, particularly well.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Well, sir, I have now discovered that was a forgery.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: So have I.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: And I'm sadly afraid, between you and me.— By the way, I hope I may speak safely before your clerk?

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Oh, quite.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: I'm almost satisfied that this bill is a forgery too. The other has been impounded, I hear. My object in coming here yesterday was, first to verify, if possible, the forgery in the case of this second bill; and next, to ask your assistance, as you had given value for the first as well as myself, in bringing the forger to justice. (HAWKSHAW looks up as in doubt)

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Really sir,—

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Oh, my dear sir! If we City men don't stand by each other in these rascally cases! But before taking any other step, there is one thing I owe to myself, as well as to you, and that is, to repay you the amount of the first forged bill.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: But you said you had given value for it?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: The more fool I! But if I am to pay twice, that is no reason you should be a loser. I've a memorandum of the amount here. (looks at his bill-book) Two hundred and twenty-seven—five. Here are notes—two hundreds a ten—and two fives—seven—and one—two —three. (counting out copper)

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Oh! pray, sir, don't trouble yourself about the coppers.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: I'm particular in these matters. Excuse me It's a little peculiarity of mine (counting out coppers)— three—four—five. There! that's off my conscience! But you've not examined the notes. (HAWKSHAW pockets the handcuffs)

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Oh, my dear sir! (putting them up)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Ah! careless, careless! (shakes his head) Luckily, I had endorsed 'em.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Really, sir, I had marked that two hundred and twenty off to bad debt a month ago. By the way, I have not the pleasure of knowing your name?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Wake, sir—Theophilus Wake, of the firm of Wake, Brothers, shippers and wharfingers, Limehouse, and Dock-street Liverpool. We have a branch establishment at Liverpool. Here's our card. (gives card)

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: So far from expecting you to repay the money, I thought you were coming to bleed me afresh with forged bill No. 2—for a forgery it is, most certainly.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Quite natural, my dear sir, quite natural—I've no right to feel the least hurt.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: And what's more, I had a detective at that desk ready to pounce upon you.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: No, really!

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: You can drop the clerk, now, Mr. Hawkshaw. (HAWKSHAW comes down, R.)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Hawkshaw! Have I the honour to address Mr. Hawkshaw, the detective, the hero of the great gold dust robberies, and the famous Trunk-line-transfer forgeries? (crosses to c.)

sp.speaker: Hawk
sp.p: I'm the man, sir. I believe —(modestly)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Sir, the whole commercial world owes you a debt of gratitude it can never repay. I shall have to ask your valuable assistance in discovering the author of these audacious forgeries.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Have you any clue?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (c.) I believe they are the work of a late clerk of ours—who got into gay company, poor lad, and has gone to the bad. He knew the Vanzellers' signature, as they were old correspondents of ours.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (R.) Is the lad in London?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: He was within a week.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p:
Can you give me a description of him? Age—
height—hair—eyes—complexion—last address—haunts —habits—associates, (significantly) any female connexion?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Unluckily I know very little or him personally. My partner, Walker Wake, can supply all the information you want.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Where shall I find him?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Here's our card. We'll take a cab and question him at our office. Or (as if struck by a sudden thought) suppose you bring him here—so that we may all lay our heads together.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: You'll not leave this office till I come back?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: If Mr. Gibson will permit me to wait.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (L.) I shall feel extremely obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: You may expect me back in half an hour at farthest (going up c., returns) egad, sir, you've had a narrow escape. I had the darbies open under the desk. (shewing handcuffs)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! how very pleasant. (takes and examines handcuffs curiously)

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: But I'll soon be down on this youngster.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: If only he hasn't left London.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Bless you—they can't leave London. Like the moths, they turn and turn about the candle till they burn their wings.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Ah! thanks to men like you. How little society is aware of what it owes its detective benefactors?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: There's the satisfaction of doing one's duty— and something else, now and then.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Ah! a good round reward.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: That's not bad; but there's something better than that.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Paying off old scores. Now, if I could only clinch the darbies on Jem Dalton's wrists.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Dalton! What's your grudge against him in particular?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: He was the death of my pal, the best mate I ever had, poor Joe Skirrit. (draws his hand across his eyes) I shall never work with such another.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Did he murder him?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p:
Not to say murder him right out. But he spoiled him—gave him a clip on the head with a neddy—
a life-preserver. He was never his own man afterwards. He left the force on a pension, but he grew sort of paralysed, and then got queer in his head. I was sitting with him the week before he died—"Jack," he says, it was Joe and Jack with us, "Jack," he says, "I lay my death at the Tiger's door"—that was the name we had for Dalton in the force. "You'll look after him, Jack," he says, "for the sake of your old mate." By— no, I won't say what I said, but I promised him to be even with Jem Dalton, and I'll keep my word.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (c.) You know this Dalton?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (R.) Know him! He has as many outsides as he has aliases. You may identify him for a felon to-day, and pull your hat off to him for a parson to-morrow. But I'll hunt him out of all his skins;—and my best night's sleep will be the day I've brought Jem Dalton to the dock!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Mr. Hawkshaw, I wish you every success!

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: But I've other fish to fry now. (going up, looks at card) Wake, brothers, Buckle's Wharf, Limehouse.

div.stage: Exit HAWKSHAW, C.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Ask anybody for our office! (aside) And if any body can tell you I shall be astonished (following him up then returning.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: I'm really ashamed to keep you waiting, sir.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Oh, I can write my letters here. (pointing to the counter) If you don't mind trusting me all alone in your office.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: My dear sir, if you were Dalton himself—the redoubtable Tiger—you couldn't steal ledgers and day-books, and there's nothing more valuable here—except, by the way, my queer old depositor, Miss Faddle's, five thousand, that she insists on Mr. Gibson keeping here in the office in gold, as she believes neither in banks nor bank-notes. And, talking of notes, I may as well lock up these you so handsomely paid me. (goes to safe, R.)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Not believe in notes! Infatuated woman! (aside) I hope he'll like mine.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (locks safe) I'll leave you to write your letters.

div.stage: Exit MR. GIBSON into his office, R.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p:
Phew! (whistles low) That's the narrowest shave I ever had! So, Jack Hawkshaw, you'll be even with Jem Dalton yet will you? You may add this day's
work to the score against him. How the old boy swallowed my soft sawder and Brummagem notes! They're beauties! It would be a pity to leave them in his hands —and five thousand shiners p'raps alongside of 'em. Come—I've my wax handy—never travel without my tools. Here goes for a squeeze at the lock of this safe. (goes to safe, R., and by means of a pick-lock applies wax to the wards of the lock by the key-hole—Music, piano)

div.stage: Enter BRIERLY, C. from L.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (hangs up hat, L.) Clerks not returned. Hawkshaw gone? (sees DALTON at safe) Holloa! who's this? Tampering with the safe? Hold hard there! (he seizes DALTON, who turns)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (aside, R.) Brierly! Hands off, young'un. Don't you know a locksmith when you see him ?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (R. C.) Gammon! Who are you? How came you here? What are you doing with that safe?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: You ask a great deal too many questions.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I'll trouble you to answer 'em.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: By what right?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I'm messenger in this office, and I've a right to know who touches a lock here.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: You messenger here? Indeed! and suppose I took to asking questions you mightn't be so keen of answering yourself—Robert Brierly!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: You know me!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Yes. And your character from your last place—Port—

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (terrified) Hush!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Your hair hasn't grown so fast but I can see traces of the prison-crop.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: For mercy's sake!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Silence for silence. Ask me no questions and I'll press for no answers.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: You must explain your business here to Mr. Gibson. I suspected you for a thief.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p:
And I know you for a jail-bird. Let's see whose information will go the farthest. There, I'll make you a fair offer, Robert Brierly. Let me pass, and [ leave this place without breathing a word to your employer that you're fresh from a sentence of penal
servitude for four years. Detain me, and I denounce you —for the convict you are! (a knock at the door, L.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (without) Mr. Brierly!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Hush! Coming, Mrs. Willoughby.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Is it a bargain?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Go—go—anything to escape this exposure. (giving him his hat, &c. from counter, L.)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (at door) There's Aby Moss, waiting for me outside. He shall blow the lad to Gibson. He may be useful to us, and I owe him one for spoiling my squeeze.

div.stage: Exit DALTON, L. C.
Enter MRS. WILLOUGHBY, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Which, I've to ask pardon for intruding, not bein' used to an office, and knowing my place I 'ope. But it's gettin' on for a quarter past eleven, Mr. Robert, and twelve's the latest they will do it, and the breakfast all set out beautiful and some parties is a gettin' impatient, which it's no more than natural, bless her, and Sam that rampagious — But whatever's the matter? You look struck all of a heap like?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Oh, nothing, nothing. It's natural, you know, a man should look queer on his wedding morning. There, go and tell May I'll be with her directly.

div.stage: Enter SAM, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Come along, Bob, we're all tired of waiting, especially this child. (sings nigger song) Come along!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (admiringly) Oh, that boy! If it ain't enough to make any grandmother's 'eart proud.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Go—go—I'll follow you—I've some business matters to attend to.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A nice state for business you're in—I don't think— There, granny. (looks at him) This is what comes of getting married! If it ain't an awful warning to a young fellow like me!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Drat your imperence.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: But the party's waiting down stairs, and we're wanted to keep 'em in spirits, so come along, granny.

div.stage: Polks out with MRS. WILLOUGHBY, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Known! Threatened! Spared by Hawkshaw— only to be denounced by this man

div.stage: Enter MOSS, L. C.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Mr. Gibson, if you please?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: He's in his office, sir—that way. (points to open door, R.)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: I remember the young man now. A convict get himself into a respectable situation. It is a duty one owes to society to put his employer on his guard. (Exit, R.)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Yes—he's gone — I can draw my breath again— I was wrong to let him go. But to have the cup at one's lip, and see it struck away—I couldn't—I couldn't—even the detective had mercy. When we're married, I'll tell Mr. Gibson all.

div.stage: Re-enter MOSS and MR. GIBSON from his office, R.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: You can question him, sir, if you don't believe me: any way I've done my duty, and that's what I look to.

div.stage: Exit MOSS, L. C.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (L.) Here's the money for the cheque, sir.

div.stage: GIBSON takes money—BRIERLY is going, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: (R.) Robert.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (L.) Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: To dress for church, sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Stay here.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: You have deceived me.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Mr. Gibson—

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: I know all—your crime—your conviction— your punishment!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Mercy! Mercy!

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: Unhappy young man.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Ah! unhappy you may well call me. I was sentenced, sir, but I was not guilty. It's true, sir, but I don't expect you to believe it—I've worked out my sentence, sir—they hadn't a mark against me at Portland —you may ask 'em—here's my ticket-of-leave, sir. You own I've been steady and industrious since I came here. By heaven's help I mean to be so still, indeed I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. G.
sp.p: I dare say, but I must think of my own credit and character. If it was buzzed about that I kept a ticket-of-leave man in my employment—

div.stage: Enter GREEN JONES, C. down R., and MAY, EMILY, MRS. WILLOUGHBY, and SAM, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (L.) Which, axin' your pardon, Mr. Gibson, we're all ready, and the cab is a waitin'

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (L.) And the parson getting cold.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (L. C.) Robert, why are you not dressed? What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Heaven help thee, my poor lass.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: You are pale you tremble—you are ill! Oh, speak, what is it?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Bear up, May. But our marriage—cannot— be—yet—awhile.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The wedding put off! (MAY stands aghast)

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No bonnets!

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: And no breakfasts!

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: By Jove!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Here's a-go!

div.stage: (together)

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Am I dreaming! Robert—what does this mean?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: It's hard to bear. Keep up your heart— I'm discharged. He knows all.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (to MR. GIBSON) Oh, sir, you couldn't have the heart—say it is not true.

sp.speaker: Gibson.
sp.p: Sorry for it. You have both deceived me— you must both leave the place.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: You hear—Come, May.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I'll go, sir. It was I deceived you, not he. Only give him a chance—

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Never heed her, sir. (music—piano till end) She'd have told you long ago, but I hadn't the heart—My poor lass! Let her bide here sir—I'll not trouble you I'll leave the country— I'll list.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Hush, hush, Robert! We were wrong to hide the truth; we are sorely punished but if you've courage to face what's before us, I have.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: My brave wench! Thank you for all your kindness, sir. Good bye, friends. Come, May, we'll go together.

div.stage: GREEN. GIBSON. BRIER. MAY. MRS. W. SAM. EMILY.
R.
L.

div.head: SCENE FIRST.— The Bridgewater Arms
div.stage: —A large gaily decorated Coffee Room, set out with tables and benches, a bar crosses the corner of room, up L., with gaily painted hogsheads ranged above it; beer engine, &c., at the head of bar, L. C.; door to street in flat, R.; door to parlour, R. 2 E.; curtained windows in flat; a piano L.; a trap leading to cellar, practicable, up stage, C., near the end of the bar; table and three chairs in front, R.; table and benches, up L.; table and benches at back, R. MOSS with bags of silver, and DALTON seated at table, R. —MALTBY waiting upon them.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: (at back of table, R.) Pint of sherry. (putting it down) Very curious! — Yes, Mr. Moss, it's a pleasure to see you, sir, at the Bridgewater Arms; though it aint the Belle Vue Gardens! worse luck!

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (R. of table) Ah! ups and downs is this lot of life, Mr. Maltby. You'll let me know when Mr. Tottie comes?

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: Ah, the subcontractor for the main sewer in the next street. Such a nuisance! stops all traffic—

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: But sends you all the navvies. It's here they're taken on, and paid you know.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: Connexion not aristocratic, but beery; we do four butts a-week at the bar, to say nothing of the concert room up stairs.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (L. of table, R.) What, the navvies like music to their malt, do they?

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: Oh, yes, sir! I introduced the arts from the West End. The roughs adore music, especially selections from the Italian Opera, and as for sentiment and sensation, if you could hear Miss St. Evremond touch them up with the "Maniac's Tear," the new sensation ballad, by a gifted composer, attached to the establishment, and sold at the bar, price one shilling: why we've disposed of three dozen "Maniac's Tears" on a pay night —astonishing how it goes down!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: With the beer?

div.stage: Enter MRS. GREEN JONES, door in flat, and comes down, L. —she wears a handsome evening dress under her shawl.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: (c. coming forward to her) Here comes Mrs Jones—gentlemen, this is the great and gifted creature I was alluding to.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (L.) Go along with your nonsense!

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: Miss St. Evremond, the great sensation balladist, formerly of the Nobility's Concerts, and her Majesty's Theatre—(aside)—in the ballet.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Proud to make the acquaintance of so gifted an artiste.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You're very obliging, I'm sure. (taking off her bonnet and shawl, and smoothing her hair, to MALTBY) How's the room to night?

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: Tidy, but nothing to what it will be. It's the navvies pay-night you know.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Navvies! oh lord! (sighs) to think of Emily St. Evremond wasting her sweetness upon an audience of navigators!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: They are not aristocratic, but they are appreciative.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Yes! poor creatures! they do know a good thing when they hear it! (to MALTBY)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: If Miss St. Evremond will oblige us with a ballad—

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: The Maniac's Tear.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: If these gentlemen wouldn't mind.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: On the contrary—we like music; don't we, Moss?

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: I doat upon it; especially Handel!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: But where's the accompanist?

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: I regret to say the signor is disgracefully screwed!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh, never mind, Jones can accompany me! (going up) Come in, Green Jones; you're wanted!

div.stage: Enter GREEN JONES with a basket of trotters, door in flat— they both come down, L.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: In the trotter line, or the tuneful?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: To accompany me on the piano! (she arranges her hair)

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Till you're ready, these gentlemen wouldn't like to try a trotter would they? A penny a set, and of this morning's boiling—if I might tempt you? They're delicious with a soupçon of pepper.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Jones, these are not your style of customers.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: Excuse me, Mr. Maltby, I'm aware trotters are not known in good society; but they go down as a relish, even with people accustomed to entreés! I liked 'em as a swell before I was reduced to them as a salesman.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: (c. to MRS. GREEN JONES) Perhaps you'd give us the Maniac's Tear?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (L. C.) I can't do it without letting down my back hair!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (R. C.) Oh, down with the back hair, by all means!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You're very kind. Jones! Where's the glass?

div.stage: (JONES produces hand-glass from basket—EMILY arranges her hair by glass)

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p: (L.—seating himself at the piano) One word of preface, gentlemen! It's a sensation ballad! scene— Criminal Ward, Bedlam! Miss St. Evremond is an interesting lunatic—with lucid intervals. She has murdered her husband— (finds basket in his way) Emmy! if you'd just shift those trotters —and her three children, and is supposed to be remonstrating with one of the lunacy commissioners on the cruelty of her confinement!

div.stage: (Music—EMILY sings a sensation ballad, "The Maniac's Tear," accompanied by her husband—all applaud)

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: (going off) Now—look sharp, Miss St. Evremond. The Wisconsin Warblers are at their last chorus.

div.stage: Exit MALTBY, L. U. E.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: (to her husband) Bye-bye, dear, till after the oncert—you know I can't be seen speaking to you while you carry that basket.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p:
True—in the humble trotter-man who would suspect the husband of the brilliant St. Evremond! There's
something romantic in it—I hover round the room—I hear you universally admired—visibly applauded—audibly adored. Oh, agony!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Now, Jones—you are going to be jealous again! I do believe jealousy's at the bottom of those trotters!

div.stage: Exit MRS. and MR. GREEN JONES, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Now's our time while the fools upstairs are having their ears tickled. You've the tools ready for jumping that crib in St. Nicholas Lane?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Yes, but tools ain't enough—I must have a clear stage, and a pal who knows the premises.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: I've managed that nobody sleeps in the place but the old housekeeper and her precious grandson.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: He's as sharp as a terrier dog—and can bite too a young varmint. If I come across him. (threateningly)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: No occasion for that— you're so violent. I've made the young man's acquaintance. I've asked him to meet me here to-night for a quiet little game—his revenge, I called it. I'll dose the lad till he's past leaving the place. You drop a hint to the old lady—she'll come to take care of him. The coast will be clear yonder.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: And the five thousand shiners will be nailed in the turning of a jemmy. If we had that young Brierly in the job—he knows the way about the place blindfold. But he's on the square, he is —bent on earning an honest livelihood.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: But I've blown him wherever he's got work. He must dance to our tune at last!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Ah! if you've got him in hand! Work him into the job, and I'll jump the crib to-night.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: He's applied to be taken on at the contract works near here. This is the pay night—Tottie, the sub-contractor, is a friend of mine—

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: He's lucky!

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p:
Yes. I find him the cash at twenty per cent, till his certificates are allowed by the engineer. 'Taint heavy interest, but there's no risk--a word from me, and he'd discharge every navvie in his gang. But I've only
to breathe jail-bird, and there's no need of a discharge. The men themselves would work the lad off the job. They are sad roughs, but they've a horror of jail-birds.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Ah! nobody likes the Portland mark. I know that I've tried the honest dodge, too.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: It don't answer.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: It didn't with me. I had a friend, like you, always after me. Whatever I tried, I was blown as a convict, and hunted out from honest men.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: And then you met me and I was good to you —wasn't I?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Yes. You were very kind.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Always allowed you handsome for the swag you brought, and put you up to no end of good things! and I'll stick by you, my dear—I never drop a friend.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: No, till the hangman takes your place at his side. (presses his elbows to his side in the attitude of a man pinioned)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Don't be disagreeable, my dear—you give me a cold shiver. Hush! here come the navvies.

div.stage: Enter the NAVIGATORS noisily, through door in flat R. C. They seat themselves at their tables, R. and L., calling, some for pots of beer, some for quarterns of gin. POTMAN and WAITERS bustle about, with MALTBY superintending and taking money. BRIERLY follows. Enter HAWKSHAW, door in flat, R. C., disguised as a navvy. He appears flustered with drink—goes to one of the tables, L., and assuming a country dialect, calls swaggeringly.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Gallon 'o beer! measter.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: A gallon?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Aye, and another when that's done—I'm in brass to night, and I stand treat. Here, mates, who'll drink? (NAVVIES crowd, with loud acclamations to his table, beer is brought—HAWKSHAW to BRIERLY, who is seated L. of table) Come, won't thou drink, my little flannel back.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: No, thank you; I've a poor head for liquor, and I've not had my supper yet.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Thou'st sure it's not pride?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Pride? I've no call for pride—I've come to try and get taken on at the works.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Well, thou looks a tough 'un. There's cast-iron Jack was smashed in the tunnel this morning. There'll be room for thee, if thou canst swing the old anchor.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: The old anchor?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Ha, ha! It's easy to see thou's no banker. Why, the pick to be sure —the groundsman's bread- winner. Halloa, mates, keep a drop for Ginger. (goes back to table)

sp.speaker: Navvies.
sp.p: Aye, aye!

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Here's the old anchor, boys, and long may we live to swing it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: The pick for ever! Hip, hip, hurrah!

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: (coming down, R.) Mr. Tottie's in the parlour, and wishes particularly to see you, Mr. Moss.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: I should think he did —say I'm coming.

div.stage: Exit MALTBY, R.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (aside to Moss) You look after the Lancashire lad—yonder he sits and I'll drop a hint to the old woman. Stay, we'd better work from the old church yard of St. Nicholas—there's a door opens into it from the crib. I'll hide the tools behind one of the tombstones.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Beautiful! Sacred to the memory of Jem Dalton's jack-in-the-box! Ha, ha, ha!

div.stage: Exeunt, MOSS into parlour, R., DALTON by the street door, R. in flat.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Here, landlord, take your change out of that. (flings a sovereign on table) Call for more beer, mates, till I come back.

div.stage: Exit, staggering like a drunken man after DALTON.

sp.speaker: 1st Navvy.
sp.p: Thou'llt come back, mate?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (at door) Aye, aye, boys, directly. Contractor's in 't parlour wi' the week's pay.

sp.speaker: 1st Navvy.
sp.p: Here's thy health!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: (sing) "For he's a jolly good fellow," &c.

div.stage: Enter GREEN JONES, L. 1 E.

sp.speaker: Green.
sp.p:
Emily is bringing down the house in the
Maniac; I can't stand it; my feelings as a husband are trampled on! But she's a trump, too, and what a talent! By heaven, if ever I get my head above water again, I won't fool away my money as I've done; no, I'll take a theatre at the west end, and bring out my wife in everything. It will be an immense success; meanwhile, 'till the pounds present themselves, let me look after the pence. Trotters, gents, trotters, penny the set, and this morning's boiling. (he goes up among tables)

sp.speaker: 1st Navvy.
sp.p: Stop till we get brass, we'll clear out thy basket.

div.stage: Exit NAVVIES, R. door, followed by GREEN JONES.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Yes, the old anchor is my last chance—I've tried every road to an honest livelihood, and, one after another, they are barred in my face. Everywhere that dreadful word, jail-bird, seems to be breathed in the air about me—sometimes in a letter, sometimes in a hint, sometimes a copy of the newspaper with my trial, and then it is the same story, sorry to part with me, no complaint to make, but can't keep a ticket-of-leave man. Who can it be that hunts me down in this way? Hawkshaw spared me; I've done no man a wrong—poor fellows like me should have no enemies. I wouldn't care for myself, but my poor lass, my brave true-hearted May; I'm dragging her down along with me. Ah! here she is.

div.stage: Enter MAY EDWARDS, poorly dressed—she has a can and some food in a bundle, door in flat, and comes down, L.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (cheerfully) Well, Robert, dear, I said I shouldn't be long; I've brought your supper.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (L.) Thank thee, darling—I'm not hungry— thou'st been out after work all day—eat thyself—thou need'st strength most.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (on his L.) Nay, dear, what will become of me if you lose heart? But if you'll be a good boy, and take your tea, (gets round in front to R., opens tin, and takes bread from bundle) I'll tell you a piece of good news— for you —for both of us.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: That will be something new.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p:
I've got a promise of work from the Sailor's Ready Made Clothing Warehouse near here. It won't
be much, but it will keep the wolf from the door till you get another situation. Have you tried if the contractor here will take you on?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Not yet. He's in yonder paying the men. He'll send for me; but I scarcely dare to ask him. Oh! May, lass, I've held on hard to hope, but it feels as if it was slipping out of my hand at last.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Robert, dear Robert, grasp it hard; so long as we do what is right, all will come clear at last; we're in kind hands, dear—you know we are.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I begin to doubt it, lass—I do, indeed.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No, no; never doubt that, or my heart will give way too—

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: And thou that has had courage for both of us. Every blow that has fallen, every door that has been shut between me and an honest livlihood, every time that clean hands have been drawn away from mine, and respectable faces turned aside as I came near them, I've come to thee for comfort, and love, and hope, and I've found them till now.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Oh, yes! what's the good of a sunshine wife? It's hard weather tries us women best, dear, you men ain't half so stout-hearted.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I'd not mind the misery so much for myself, 'tis for thee.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: I don't complain—do I?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Never! But, nevertheless, I've brought thee to sorrow, and want, and shame. Till I came back to thee thou hadst friends, work, and comforts. But since Mr. Gibson discharged us off, the blight that has followed me, has reached thee too, the bravest, honestest, brightest lass that ever doubled a man's joys, and halved his burdens. Oh! it's too bad; (rises) it kills the heart out of me—it makes me mad! (crosses to R.)

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (following him) I tell you, 'twill all come clear at last, if we are only true to ourselves —to each other. I've work promised, and perhaps you may be taken on here. I spy bright days before us still.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p:
Bright days! I can't see them through the prison cloud that stands like a dark wall between me and honest labour. May, lass, I sometimes think I had
better let it all go—run—'list—make a hole in the water, anything that would rid thee of me; thou could'st make thy way alone.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Oh, Robert, that is cruel! nothing others could do to us could hurt me like those words from you; we are man and wife, and we'll take life as man and wife should, hand-in-hand: where you go. I will go; where you suffer, I will be be there to comfort; and when better times come, as come they will—we will thank God for them together.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I'll try to hope.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: And you won't heed the black thoughts that come over you when you're alone?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I'll do my best to fight 'em off.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: That's a brave dear; I'm only going to the warehouse, I shall be back soon. Good-bye, dearest. Remember, when the clouds are thickest, the sun still shines behind them.

div.stage: Exit, door in flat.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Bless that brave bright heart; she puts strength into me, in spite of the devilish doubts that have got their claws about my throat. Yes, I will try once more. (the NAVIGATORS come noisily out of parlour, R., and re-seat themselves at the tables, R. and L.)

div.stage: Enter MOSS, from parlour, R.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (speaking off) So, all paid at last?

div.stage: Re-enter DALTON, door in flat, and HAWKSHAW, after him.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (down, R., to MOSS) All right, the lad's coming. I've tipped the old woman the office, and planted the tools. (at table, R.)

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (crosses to L., then tapping BRIERLY on the shoulder) All the gang ha' gotten their brass—Tottie's takin' on men now, my little flannel-back. Thou go in, and put on a bold face—Tottie likes chaps as speaks up to him. (HAWKSHAW returns to his MATES)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: If this chance fail—God, help us both!

div.stage: Exit into parlour, R. 1 E. (NAVVIES at the table, clamour and fight, and shout over their drink, MOSS glances at BRIERLY as he passes)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: There he goes! (NAVVIES clamour)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: It would be a pity to let a ticket-of-leave man in among all those nice, sober, well-behaved young men. (clamour)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: I must blow him again; he ought to be near the end of his tether, now. Enter SAM WILLOUGHBY, door in flat, and comes down, C. Here comes our young friend. (coaxingly to SAM WILLOUGHBY) Ah, my dear—so you've come out for a little hanky-panky with old Moss. Sit down. My friend, Mr. Walker. What'll you have?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I don't care—I'm game for anything from sherry to rum-shrub. Suppose we begin with a brandy and soda, to cool the coppers?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (calls) Brandy and soda, Maltby.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I had an awful go in of it last night at the balls, and dropped into a lot of 'em, like a three-year-old! (imitates action of billiard-play with his walking-cane for a cue)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Billiards, too! Lord! what a clever young chap you are! (MALTBY brings soda water and brandy)

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (sits at back of table) Yes, I know a thing or two, (takes glass) I wasn't born blind, like a terrier pup— I rayther think. But you promised me my revenge, you old screw. (drinks) That's the tipple to steady a chap's hand. Now, fork out the pictures, old boy.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (shuffling cards, R.) Oh, what a boy you are! What shall it be this time?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A round or two of brag to begin with, and a few deals at Blind Hookums for a wind up. (as he deals, enter BRIERLY from inner room, R.)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Heaven be thanked, another chance yet!

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (as BRIERLY passes) Well, my little flannel-back, has he taken you on?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Yes, I'm to come to work to-morrow morning. I'm in Ginger's gang.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: I'm Ginger. Come, let's wet thy footing.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: My last shilling! (throws it down) It's all I have, but you're welcome.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p:
Nay, it shan't be said Ginger Bill ever cleared a chap out neither. I'll pay for thy footing, and thou'lt stand beer thy first pay night. Here, measter, a gallon
to wet t' new chap's name. Bob, we'll christen thee, cause thou hadst but a shillin'—Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Navvies.
sp.p: (laugh they all drink) Here's Bob's health!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (L. C., recognizing SAM) Sam Willoughby, in this place, and over the devil's books, too. Oh! I'm sorry to see this —sorry —sorry. Poor old woman! If she knew!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (calling) Best card! (shewing a card) First stake!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Stop a minute—ace of diamonds!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: First stake to you. Hang it! never mind, (deal) one can't lose much at this game—I go a tizzy (puts a stake on cards)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: A shilling.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Five.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: I stand.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Ten.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A sovereign! thirty-one! Third stake, and the brag. (shews his cards) Pair royal—pair—ace of spades. Fork over the shiners.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Oh, dear! oh, dear! I'm ruined—ruined. (pays sovereign)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (calls) Two colds without.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Now, for my deal. (he deals three cards to each— MALTBY brings brandy)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Best card! First stake. I stand.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I brag. Hang peddling with tizzies—half a crown.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Five. (MOSS looks at SAM's hand, and signals to DALTON)

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ten.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: A sovereign.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Oh! dear, what a boy it is! How much have you got in your pocket?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Lots! I'm paid quarterly now. Had my quarter to-day! Another cold without. (calls) Let's see—I'll hold on. (draws card) Thirty-four—overdrawn—confound it! Now let's see your hand. (to DALTON)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Three pairs—fives, trays, deuces, and the knave of clubs.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Hang it all! How is a man to stand against such cards?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: How is a man to stand against such play? He was looking over your cards, and see—(seizing a card from MOSS's lap) —the ace of diamonds! Handy to make pairs royal! Sam, if you won't believe me, believe your own eyes: you're being cheated, robbed. You old villain—you should be ashamed of yourself!

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Oh! dear, oh, dear! to say such things to a man at my time of life.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: We're not to be bullied.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (threateningly) You give me back my money! (MALTBY comes down)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: I shan't! Here, Mr. Maltby.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: Come, be off. I can't have any disturbance here, Mr. Moss is a most respectable man, and his friends are as respectable as he is, and as for you if you won't leave the room quietly—you must be made to.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Who'll make me? Come on, (squaring) both of you! Stand up to 'em, Bob, I'm not afraid! (NAVIGATORS gather round)

div.stage: Enter MRS. WILLOUGHBY, door in flat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (R. C.) It's his voice—which well I know it. Oh! Sam—Sam, I've found you at last!

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Well, suppose you have—what then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: What then! Oh! dear—oh! dear. And I've run myself into that state of trimmle and perspiration, and if it hadn't been for the gentleman I might have been east, and west, and high, and low, but it's at the "Bridgewater Arms," you'll find him he says—and here I have found you, sure enough—and you come 'ome with me this minute.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (R.) Ah! you'd better go home with the old lady!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (R. C.) And if you take my advice, you'll send him to bed without his supper.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (C., MRS. WILLOUGHBY pushing him away) I ain't a going. Now, you give me my money—I'm not going to stand any nonsense.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p:
(R. C.) And this is what he calls attending elocution class of a night, and improvin' of his mind— and me a toilin' and a moilin' for him which I'm his own
grandmother, gentlemen, and him the only one of three. (still holding him)

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: It's no use, Granny, I'm not a child to be tied to your apron strings—you've no right to be naggin' and aggravatin', and coming after a chap, to make him look small this way. I don't mind—I shan't stir. There! (he flings down his cap on the table, and sits on it, swinging his legs)

sp.speaker: Mr. W.
sp.p: Oh! dear—oh! dear—he'll break my heart, he will.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (c.) Sam, my lad, listen to me, if you won't hearken to her. (crosses, L.) A bad beginning makes a bad end, and you're beginning badly: the road you're on leads downwards, and once in the slough at the bottom o't—oh! trust one who knows it—there's no working clear again. You may hold out your hand—you may cry for help you may struggle hard—but the quicksands are under your foot—and you sink down, down, till they close over your head.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (seated, L.) Hear the little flannel-back. He talks like a missionary, he do. (all laugh)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Go home, my lad—go home with her—be a son to her —love her as she has loved thee—make her old days happy—be sober, be steady, and when you're a grown man, and her chair's empty at t'chimney corner, you'll mayhap remember this day, and be thankful you took the advice of poor, hunted-down, broken-hearted Bob Brierly.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (who has betrayed signs of feeling while BRIERLY has been speaking) I don't know —I feel so queer—and —don't look at me. (to MRS. WILLOUGHBY—gets off table crosses to her) I've been a regular bad'un, Granny—I'm very sorry I'll put on the curb—I'll pull up —that is, I'll try.

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: (rises) Oh! bless him for those words! Bless you! my own dear boy. (crosses to BRIERLY) And you too, Mr. Brierly—which if the widow's blessing is worth while it's yours, and many of them. Oh! dear— oh! dear. (cries—gets out her handkerchief, and in doing so drops her purse and keys—MOSS picks up the purse— MRS. WILLOUGHBY catches his eye as he does so—DALTON unobserved by all picks up the keys)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (passes back to L.) Nay, don't thank me. It's late now. Go home—Sam, give her your arm.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Here's your purse, old lady. (making a final attempt on SAM) What, you won't stay and make a night of it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: I'll trouble you not to speak to my grandson. If ever an old man was ashamed of his grey hairs, it's you ought to be. Come, Sam.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (aside) Baulked.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: No—I didn't give her back her keys.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: (turning to MOSS) If I wasn't a going to turn over a new leaf—Oh, wouldn't I like to pitch into you!

div.stage: Exit SAM and MRS. WILLOUGHBY.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (pretending to be very drunk) And so should I —an old varmint and so would all of us; —you're bad enough for a tommy shop-keeper.

sp.speaker: Navvies.
sp.p: Aye that he is— ought to be ashamed of himself.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (crosses to c.) And who accuses me? A nice chap, this, to take away honest folk's characters!

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Stow that! He's one of us now—a regular blue-stocking. Tottie's taken him on! He's paid his footing—eh, mates?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Aye—Aye.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Here's Bob's health, mates.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Aye—Aye.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Stop; (goes up c. towards L. table) before you drink that health, best know the man you're drinking to. You're a rough lot, I know; but you're honest men.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Oh, man, if you've a heart —(rises)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: I owe you one—I always pay my debts— (to NAVVIES) You're not felons, nor company for felons—for jail-birds.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Jail-birds!

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Aye—jail-birds. Ask him how long it is since he served his four years at Portland. (HAWKSHAW goes up, crosses, and sits quietly at head of table, L.) Look!— he turns pale—his lip falls; he can't deny it. (BRIERLY turns away)

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Who knows, lads—perhaps he's repented.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No—no. (grumbling) No jail-bird—no convict— no ticket-of-leaver. — (they turn away from BRIERLY)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Aye, mates—it's true I was convicted, but I wasn't guilty. I served my time. I came out an altered man. I tried hard to earn an honest livelihood (they all turn away) Don't all turn away from me! Give me a chance—only a chance.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: No—no.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Nay, then, my last hope is gone—I can fight no longer! (throws his head on his hands in despair)

div.stage: The NAVIGATORS retire up, HAWKSHAW pretending to be very drunk, appears to sleep with head on table. The NAVIGATORS drop off, and exit D. F. one by one.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (to DALTON) Honesty's bowled out at last! It's our game now. (puts his hand on BRIERLY'S shoulder) I say, my friend—

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Eh? (looking up) You! The man who told them! (fiercely)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (L.) Yes—yes; but don't put yourself in a passion.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Only tell me —Is it you who have followed me in this way?—who have turned all against me?—who have kept me from earning honest bread?

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: But why, man, why? I had done you no wrong.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Ask him. (pointing to DALTON) He's an old friend of yours.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I don't know him—yet—I've seen that face before. Yes, it is—Jem Downy! Thou villain! (he seizes him) I know thee now. Thou shalt answer to me for all this misery.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Easy does it, Bob. Hands off, and let's take things pleasantly.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Not content with leading me into play, and drink, and devilry, with making me your tool, with sending me to a prison, it's you that have dogged me —have denounced me as a convict.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Of course you didn't think any but an old friend would have taken such an interest in you.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Did you want to close all roads against me but that which leads to the dock?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: You see, when a man's in the mud himself and can't get out of it, he don't like to see another fight clear. Come, honest men won't have anything to do with you—best try the black sheep—we ain't proud. (all sit, R.) We've a job in hand will be the making of all three. (fills his glass) Here, drink, and put some heart into you. (BRIERLY drinks) That's your sort—a lad of spirit—1 said there was real grit in him—didn't I, Mossey?

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: You always gave him the best of characters.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Is it a bargain?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: There! Tip us the cracksman's crook—so! (shakes hands with a peculiar grip)

div.stage: Enter MAY EDWARDS, door in flat.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (c.) Robert—not here? (sees him) Ah—there he is! (going—pauses) Who are those with him?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Now a caulker to clench the bargain. (DALTON and BRIERLY drink)

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (in pain) Ah—Robert!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: You here—lass?

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Oh, these petticoats!

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: You're not wanted here, young woman.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: He is my husband, sir. He is not strong—the drink will do him harm.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Brandy do a man harm! It's mother's milk—take another sip. (fills BRIERLY'S glass again) To your girl's good health!

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Robert, dear—come with me.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Have you got work?

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: No—not yet.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: No more have I, lass. The man took me on— it was the old story.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Oh, Robert—come!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I shall stay with my friends here—thou go home, and don't sit up for me.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: (imploringly) Robert!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: I've my reasons.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Come, are you going?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (MAY clings to him) Stand off, lass. You used to do what I bid you ——stand off I say. (he shakes himself free from her)

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: Oh, Robert, Robert! (staggers back to table, L., and sits)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (aside) I must—or they'll not trust me.

sp.speaker: May.
sp.p: These men! to what have they tempted him in his despair. They shan't drive me away. (aside) I'll watch.

div.stage: Exit, door in flat, after a mute appeal to BRIERLY.
(the tables have been before this cleared of all the navvies except HAWKSHAW, who lies with his head on the table as if dead drunk—MOSS rises and goes down, R.)

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: (re-entering from bar L. U. E.—shaking HAWKSHAW by the shoulder) Now, my man—we're shutting up the bar.

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: Shut up. I'm shut up. Good night. (lets his head fall)

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: (coming down) It's no use, he won't go, and I'm wanted in the concert room.

div.stage: Exit MALTBY, L. U. E., (calling) Bar closed!

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (to DALTON, suspiciously pointing to HAWKSHAW) There's a party—

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: (rising) Eh? (shaking HAWKSHAW) Holloa, wake up! (HAWKSHAW grunts)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: He's in a deplorable state of intoxication.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Yes, he's got his cargo, no danger in him— now for business. First and foremost, no more of this. (pockets the bottle—to BRIERLY) You've heard the job we have in hand?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Yes, but you've not told me where it is, or why you want my help?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: It's old Gibson's office. The five thousand you know—you know where it's kept.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: And you'll take us to it?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: That's the ticket, then we may as well start.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Now?

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: Now. My rule is, never put off till to-morrow the crib I can crack to-day. Besides, you might change your mind.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: One has heard of such things.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: You crane—

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: I'll get a cab. (going)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: And I'll get another—we'd best go single. (following him)

sp.speaker: Dalton.
sp.p: No, it wouldn't be polite to leave Mr. Brierly —(aside) I don't half trust him—don't let him out of your sight.

div.stage: Exit door in flat.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: If he'll only leave me for a moment. (aside)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: (crosses in front to R., sitting) He's carried off the bottle, and the bar's shut up, or we might have a little refreshment.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: Perhaps, if you went to the landlord

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: No, I'd rather stay with you—I like your company, uncommon.

div.stage: Enter MALTBY, L. U. E., with a wine basket and a candle.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: Here's Mr. Tottie standing champagne round to the Wisconsin Warblers, and the bar stock all out, and the waiters in bed! I must go down to the cellar myself—very humiliating! (goes to trap near bar) What with the light, and what with the liquor—I say, Mr. Moss, if you would lend me a hand?

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (aside) I might give him the information. (to MALTBY) Let me help you, sir. (goes to trap)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Then I'll go too. (MALTBY opens the trap)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: The stairs are steep—two's quite enough.

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: But I'm so fond of your company.

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: If you'll hold the light. (BRIERLY takes it and MALTBY goes down)

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (aside) A word 'll do it. (going down—MOSS takes candle from him and gets between him and MALTBY)

sp.speaker: Moss.
sp.p: Allow me. The light will do best in the middle. (MOSS descends)

sp.speaker: Maltby.
sp.p: (from below) Now, then!

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: (rapidly closes the trap, and stands upon it) Now's the time. (seizes the pen that stands on the bar, and writes, reading as he writes quickly) "To Mr. Gibson, Peckham. The office will be entered to-night; I'm in it to save the property, and secure the robbers—R. Brierly." But who'll take it?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: (who has got up and read the letter over his shoulder) I will.

sp.speaker: Brier.
sp.p: You?

sp.speaker: Hawk.
sp.p: I, (pulls off his rough cap, wig, and whiskers, and speaks in his own voice) Hawkshaw, the detective! (gives him a pistol) Take this—I'll be on the look out.

div.stage: (HAWKSHAW lets his head fall again as DALTON re-appears beckoning at the door, and MOSS re-appears from the trap —closed in)

div.head: SCENE SECOND.—A Street in the City—Moonlight.
div.stage: Enter MRS. WILLOUGHBY and SAM, L. she is searching her pocket.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: You're sure you had 'em at the public?

sp.speaker: Mrs. W.
sp.p: Certain sure, my dear, leastways, I let myself out with the big street door, so I couldn't have left that in the kitchen window, and I'd the little ones all in my pocket, which I noticed a hole in it only yesterday— and it's best holland at one and six, and only worn three years, and they ain't dropped into my skirt, nor they ain't a hanging to my crinoline.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh, bother, granny, we can't have a regular Custom House search in the street; let's go back to the public, perhaps they've found them.
